flows.name: PLH module - One on one time baby

actions.text: Today's skill is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Baby.
One-on-one time is an important stepping stone to forming a positive relationship with your baby and achieveing your parenting goal!

Take a moment to reflect on the time you have spent with your baby. How many days in the past week did you do something fun together? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Well done for spending time with your baby, it makes all the difference!
We know it is hard to find time in our busy lives. Well done for trying your best!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Learning how to spend positive One-on-One Time with your baby will take time and dedication.
Would you like to receive some tips to help you succeed?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Do it every day!

Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

2. Be close to your baby. 

Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.

3. Let your baby take the lead!

Babies need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your baby!

Give just enough help to let it be the baby’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your baby gets frustrated, you can reassure them by gently stroking their back.

4. Observe your baby. 

See what facial expressions your baby is making. Notice what your baby is interested in or looking at.
Listen to the sounds or words your baby is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your baby!

5. Play with your baby!

Babies learn through play! Help your baby explore the world through the five senses. Let your baby use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your baby, they will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!

It is okay for your baby to want to do many different things. Your baby’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a siren, the feeling of a breeze, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your baby.

6. Talk to your baby.

Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!

Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your baby is doing.
Would you like to get a comic on how to communicate with your baby?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: "You are such a beautiful person"

(1)

Parent: "Buh, buh, buh, big baby!"

Baby: "Buh, buh, buh…"

(2)

Parent: "And then there were two green parrots in the mango tree!"

(3)

Parent: "And now I am cleaning your toes, and your feet, and your knees…"

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done! You have learnt another skill and have earned yourself a badge!
You have made great progress towards achieveing your goal of improving your relationship with your child! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be very proud of yourself!
Do you have time today to try and spend 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your baby?
Great! Use the tips you have learnt today and have fun! One-on-One Time is a great way to form a positive relationship with your baby.
That's okay! If you don't have time today, set time aside tomorrow. You and your baby will gain a lot from this.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here is a video on One-on-One Time!
Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your baby!

flows.name: PLH module - One on one time child

actions.text: Today's skill is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Children.
One-on-one time is an important stepping stone to forming a positive relationship with your child and achieveing your parenting goal!

Take a moment to reflect on the time you have spent with your teen. How many days in the past week did you do something fun together? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Well done for spending time with your child, it makes all the difference!
We know it is hard to find time in our busy lives. Well done for trying your best!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Learning how to spend positive One-on-One Time with your child will take time and dedication.
Would you like to receive some tips to help you succeed?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Spend at least five minutes with each child.

Even 5 minutes a day of quality time makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, try to find time for each individual child. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.

2. Give your child your full attention.

Make sure you will not be interrupted. Finish all your chores, switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.

3. Let your child choose the activity.

Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?"
Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t okay, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.
If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

4. Follow your child's lead.

Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.

5. Use words to describe what your child is doing.

Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

6. Have fun!

One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.
Would you like to get a comic about following your child's lead?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: "I see you are playing quietly with the lego with concentration, Alex."

(1)

Parent: "Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall with those legos."

Child: "It is for cows."

(2)

Parent: "It will keep the cow safe!"

Child: "Now you can help me build a house for our family to sleep in!"

(3)

Parent: "This house is going to keep our family warm and dry. You are such a good builder, Alex!"

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done! You have learnt another skill and have earned yourself a badge!
You have made great progress towards achieveing your goal of improving your relationship with your child! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be very proud of yourself!
Do you have time today to try and spend 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your child?
Great! Use the tips you have learnt today and have fun! One-on-One Time is a great way to form a positive relationship with your child.
That's okay! If you don't have time today, set time aside tomorrow. You and your child will gain a lot from this.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your child!

flows.name: PLH module - One on one time teen

actions.text: Today's skill is about spending One-on-One Time with Our Teen.
One-on-one time is an important stepping stone to forming a positive relationship with your teen and achieveing your parenting goal!

Take a moment to reflect on the time you have spent with your baby. How many days in the past week did you do something fun together? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Well done for spending time with your teen, it makes all the difference!
We know it is hard to find time in our busy lives. Well done for trying your best!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Learning how to spend positive One-on-One Time with your teen will take time and dedication.
Would you like to receive some tips to help you succeed?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. 
Choose a time when you and your teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.

2. Let your teen choose the activity.
Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!

Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.

3. Follow your teen's lead!
Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

4. Give your teen all of your attention. 
Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.
Look at your teen. Nodding or “I see” shows your teen you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.

5. Show your teen you are really listening.

You can even try rephrasing back what your teen says when they speak to you. For example, when your teen says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.

6. Have fun!

One-on-One Time with your teen can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after spending time with your teen.
Would you like to get a comic about giving your teen love and support when they share difficult emotions with you?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: “How are you doing, Andy?”

Teen (looking sad): “I wish I could hang out with my friends.”

(1)

Parent (thinking): "Hmmm…that can wait…"

(2)

Parent (looks back to teen): “I understand it is hard to be separate from your friends. Especially since I am sure they are missing you, too. Let’s think of some ways that you could reach out to them.”

(3)

Teen: "Maybe I can make a TikTok video to share with them. But I am not sure how…can you help me?”

Parent: “I would be happy to help and would like to know more about TikTok, too!”

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done! You have learnt another skill and a have earned yourself a badge!
You have made great progress towards achieveing your goal of improving your relationship with your child! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be very proud of yourself!
Do you have time today to try and spend 5 minutes of One-on-One Time with your teen?
Great! Use the tips you have learnt today and have fun! One-on-One Time is a great way to form a positive relationship with your teen.
That's okay! If you don't have time today, set time aside tomorrow. You and your teen will gain a lot from this.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Here's an audio message about spending one-on-one time with your teen!

Today's skill is teaching you how to keep calm and manage stress in our lives. Taking care of yourself is important so you can take care of others and build positive relationships. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.

Try and think back to the last week and your emotions. How many days did you feel very stressed as a parent/caregiver? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Great to hear that your stress levels are manageable! Whenever you feel stressed, take a deep breath – you are doing amazing.
We understand that this is a stressful time. Remember that you are not alone. We are here to help!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling angry, overwhelmed, stressed or worried.
That sounds like it would be a helpful skill to learn? Shall we practice taking a pause together?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Let's take a pause together! Take a deep breath and ask yourself, "What am I thinking?"

Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense. 
Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths. 
Now, expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room. 
Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different.
Would you like to get a comic on Taking a Pause?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

“How am I going to get through this?”

(1)

“Whatever it is, I am okay.” 

(2)

“Breathe in. Breathe out."

(3)

“I can do this. We will get through it together.”

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done! You have learnt how to Take a Pause and have earned yourself a badge!
You have made great progress towards achieveing your goal of improving your relationship with your child! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be very proud of yourself!

Over the next few days, try taking a pause whenever you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Child!
Here is a video about how to keep calm and manage stress.
Here's an audio message to help you take a pause!
Thank you for making this commitment to improve the life of your children. It shows you really care!
How did the above message make you feel?
We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.
Accepting praise can be difficult. Once you learn to take a compliment, it can make you feel great! Praising others is also a great, as it makes other people happy!

Let's take a moment to reflect on the last week. How many days have you praised your child? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Wonderful that you are praising your child! This helps them feel seen and loved – your encouragement means a lot.

We all sometimes feel like our children are causing more negativity than positivity. Try to see through negative attitudes and praise any positive behaviour you notice. With time, you will see the change!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!
Would you like to receive three simple steps to get it right?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Be positive.

Praise your child for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

2. Be specific.

Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'

3. Be enthusiastic.

Really mean it when you say it! The more real you are the better it will feel.
Would you like a comic on how to praise your child?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: “Thank you for being quiet while I talked to my boss. I appreciate it! Here, you can use my phone to WhatsApp your friends”

(1)

Teen: “Thanks! I really want to see how they are doing.”

(2)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Well done you have gained another badge! You have learnt the three steps to praise and you are one step closer to achieving your goal of improving your relationship with your child! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you are a amazing parent!
Do you feel confident using what you learnt about praise with your own family?
Amazing! We love to see it! Look for 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

That's okay! Sometimes things take time! You can review this skill at any time in the Melp Menu. At the end of the day, think of all of the positive things that happened. Once you begin recognising positive behaviour around you, it will be easier to start voicing them. With time, praise will come easy to you.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video on the importance of praise and how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!
Here's an audio message on how you can bring more attention to positive behaviour by praising your child!
Today's skill is about learning how to ignore negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours like whining or tantrums.

Your child’s behaviour might at first get worse, but with time they will learn that it does not work and your child's behaviour will improve! Be consistent and patient. And make sure that you are also giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times. You can do it!

Looking back, how many days in the past week did you shout, scream, or yell at your children? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Well done! Brain science shows if you control your anger when your child misbehaves, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
It can be difficult to control our anger, especially when they make us really angry. Take a deep breath, and be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
Would you like to receive six simple steps on how to reduce negative attention seeking and demanding behaviour like tantrums?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Try to redirect your child's attention.

When they start demanding for something or whining, first try to redirect them to a positive behaviour or activity. Praise them for that positive behaviour!

2. Make sure it is a behaviour you can ignore.

These are behaviours like whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other negative attention seeking and demanding behaviours that might make us think of the child as a bad child. But there are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
If we respond to these behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention. They sometimes also learn that if they increase the demand, they will get their way.
For example, if your child whines for sweets at the store, you might initially say “no” but then give in to your child when they start to have a tantrum. This happens to all of us!

3. Ignore the behaviour not your child.

Ignoring behaviour means removing physical and verbal attention. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
This takes time AND patience. Normally your child will try to test you and behave worse. This is a good time to Take a Pause and Keep Calm.

4. Praise your child immediately for the next positive behaviour.

Having a tantrum can be just as traumatic and difficult for your child as it is for you. Make sure you give your child plenty of positive attention and love as soon as they have calmed down.

At this time, it is more important that you involve your child in a positive activity instead of talking about what just happened. You can do that later like at night or the next day. Right now your child needs love.

5. Be consistent when ignoring.

Your child's behaviour might continue to get worse.  It is important that you continue to ignore the behaviour. Often, your child's response will grow more agitated when you start ignoring a specific behaviour as your child tries to test your resolve. Try to remain consistent. Over time, your child will learn that the demanding behaviour no longer works.

6. Make sure you are giving your child plenty of positive attention at other times.

Children need attention. If children get plenty of attention for just being themselves, as well as for the “good” things that they do, it helps them to feel good about themselves, and they do more of what they are asked.

If you find yourself ignoring your child's behaviour a lot, it is either because you are not being consistent (sometimes ignoring and sometimes giving in) OR you are not spending enough positive time with your child. One-on-One Time is super important!
Would you like to receive a comic on ignoring your child's negative behaviour?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Baby: I want more cool drink.

(1)

Parent: You have had enough, Maya. The rule is only one glass of cool drink.

(2)

Baby: But I WANT it! Give me!

Parent: David, you are eating your dinner so nicely.

(3)

Baby: Waaaaaa! Waaaaaa! WAAAAAA!

Parent: David, please fetch the custard from the counter.

(4)

Baby: Waaaaaa! Waaaaaa! WAAAAAA!

(5)

Parent: It is nice to see you sitting quietly, Maya. Here, have some delicious custard with us.

(6)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done you have gained yourself another badge! You have learnt how to ignore your child's negative behaviour!
You are one step closer to achieving your goal of improving your child's behaviour! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, your are a superparent!
Are you ready to try ignoring negative behaviour?

That's great! Over the next few days, identify one negative attention-seeking behaviour that you can first redirect and then ignore if it continues. Remember to ignore the behaviour, not your child! It's not easy, but if you are patient and give it time, it really works. You can do this!
That is okay! Ignoring bad behaviour can be hard. You can always review what you learnt today in the Main Menu and build your confidence. You got this!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Today's skill is about keeping your child safe online.
Our children and teens are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps them stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
Would you like to receive some tips that can help keep your child safe online?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Learn about risks and dangers.

• Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.

• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography

• Teens sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos of themselves.

• Cyberbullying from other young people and strangers.
This does not mean we should ban our children from spending time online. It just means that we need to learn how to protect them in a new world.

2. Tech fixes to protect your children online.

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/

• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/

• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/

• Cover webcams when not in use.

3. Create healthy and safe online habits.

Involve your child or teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
Create device-free spaces and times in your house
(eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

Child tech agreement: https://www.esafety.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-01/Our%20Family%20Tech%20Agreement_0.pdf
Teen tech agreement: https://www.childnet.com/ufiles/Family-Agreement.pdf

Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!
Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
 Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

4. Spend time with your child or teen online.

Get to know how your child experiences the digital world.
Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.
Talk to your teen on how to report things that aren't OK.

Common Sense Media has great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.
https://www.commonsensemedia.org/app-reviews"

5. Build open communication and trusting relationships.

Tell your children that if they experience something online (or anywhere) that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

6. Report and seek help.

Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals and the Child Helpline in your country to get support if you or your children experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
Would you like a comic on discussing online activities with your child?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: "Shani, have you done your homework?"
 

Child: "Just a minute, I'm finishing this tiktok video"

(1)

Parent: "You are a really great dancer! Tell me about why you like it."

Child: "All my friends are on it. I have more than 600 likes and 120 followers."

Parent: "I’m proud of how well you dance, Shani. But we need to make sure you are safe on this. I know your friends look at TikTok, but with an open account there are also paedophiles who look at videos of teenagers. Paedophiles are older people who want to attack young children and teens."

(2)

Parent: "Let’s look together online at how we can keep this fun for you but also safe. Look – you can make your account private and control who follows you. So you can accept people you know but not strangers. Can we make a rule together that you can use TikTok but with a private account? I trust you to know who to accept!"

(3)

Parent: "I’m proud of you Shani..."

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Amazing! You have learnt about how to keep your child safe online, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of keeping your child safe! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!

Over the next few days, use one of these tips for online safety. Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP towards keeping your child safe online. Good for you!
Here's a video to help you keep your children safe online.
Here's an audio message to help you keep your children safe online.
Today's skill is about learning about how to keep safe online.
We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps us stay positive…but it also presents risks and dangers.
Would you like to receive some tips that can help keep youself safe online?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Learn about risks and dangers.

• Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
• Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
• Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
• Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.

2. Quick tech fixes.

• Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/entertainment-search-engines/
• Set up parental controls.
https://www.internetmatters.org/parental-controls/
• Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
https://www.internetmatters.org/blog/parental-controls/social-media/
• Cover webcams when not in use.

3. Create healthy and safe online habits.

You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).

4. Maintain privacy.

Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are!
Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).

5. Report and seek help.

Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.

INHOPE Hotlines: https://www.inhope.org/EN#hotlineReferral
IWF portals: https://report.iwf.org.uk/en
Child Helpline: https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/

Amazing! You have learnt about online safety, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of keeping your child safe! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!

Over the next few days, use one of these tips for online safety. Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP towards keeping your child safe online. Good for you!
Here's a video to help you keep yourself safe online.
Here's an audio message to help you keep yourself safe online.
Today's skill is about learning how to cope with your baby crying.

The sound of a baby crying can be very distressing, especially for a parent. It is completely natural to want to make it stop. You might also think that you are not a good parent or that your baby is crying to spite you. But all babies cry. It is one of the main ways a baby can tell you that something is wrong.
Would you like to receive some tips to help you when your baby cries?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Why do babies cry?

Crying is a normal part of your baby's development. Sometimes babies even have crying patterns. Crying usually increases at 2-3 weeks old and is generally highest when your baby is around 6 to 8 weeks. Often babies will start crying less around 3 to 4 months. Of course, remember that every baby is different!

2. Respond as soon as you can.

Go to your baby when you hear them crying. You will not spoil your baby by picking them up. Babies who are carried and cuddled frequently, during both fussy and contented periods, may actually cry less.

3.  Check to see why your baby is crying.

There are lots of reasons why babies cry. It might be hunger, pain, too much going on, rough handling, feeling cold/hot, wanting contact or attention, or feeling irritable. Babies can cry when they sense tension in the room. And sometimes they cry for no reason at all!

4. Comfort your baby.

Try swaddling, gently rocking, or singing or soft music. You might need to feed your baby or change their diaper. They may be too hot or too cold. Or maybe they just need to be held. Take a Pause and try to relax - your baby can actually sense tension from you, too!

5. Take a break!

If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe place and walk away for a bit. Stay nearby so that you can monitor your baby. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
Call someone for help - a family member, a friend. Sometimes just talking with someone is enough, but if you feel overwhelmed, ask someone for help. Calling for help is a sign of strength.

6. Be gentle and patient with yourself.

We know that this is not easy. You are not a bad parent if your baby continues to cry after you have done all you can to calm them. You are doing your best!
Would you like a comic on copng with a crying baby?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent 1: "We should do something."

Parent 2: "Okay, I'll try feeding them."

Baby: "aaaaaaaa"

(1)

Baby: "aaaaaaaa"

Parent 1:  "What is wrong with them?"

Parent 2: "I don't know. It has been an hour and they are still crying. I cannot take it anymore. They are driving me crazy, I just want to shake them!"

(2)

Parent 2: "I can see that this has been a stressful night for you. How about you get some sleep while I take Frankie into the other room. I will try wrapping them up in a blanket."

Parent 1: "Thank you. I was getting so angry at myself."

(3)

Parent 1: "How did you manage to get them to sleep?"

Parent 2: "I think they wore themselves out but we should take them to the clinic tomorrow morning."

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

You are a star! You have learnt how to cope with a crying baby and have gotten another badge!  You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of improving your child's behaviour! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be proud of yourself!
Over the next few days, use some of these tips when your baby is crying. Remember that there are no bad parents. We are all learning here!
Here's a video that might help you when your baby cries.
Here's an audio message to help you when your baby cries.
Today's skill is about learning how to keep your children safe in your community.
You are not alone! Parents all over the world say they worry about keeping their children safe.
One helpful way is to create a map with your child or teen that identifies the safe and unsafe places in the community.
Would you like to create a map together?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Step 1: What are important places in our community?

• Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
• Draw a map of your child or teen’s community, with pictures of all the main places like streets, your house, school, shops, places your teen visits...

Step 2:  Which places are safe and unsafe? 

• Discuss which areas on your map are safe for teenagers – CIRCLE these.
• Discuss which areas on your map are unsafe for teenagers – CROSS those off. 
• What makes a place safe or unsafe? 
• Are there plans you could make together to keep your child or teen safer?

Step 3: Where can you get support?

• Sometimes, we can find ourselves in trouble.
• Discuss together where you and your child or teen can get support or help when you face a crisis – MARK those areas with a little object like a stone or piece of paper. 
• Some helpful places may include home, school, police station, clinic.

Step 4: Online map

• Draw pictures of the apps and websites they use
• Praise your child for how good they are at using the web!
• Talk about which ones might be unsafe. Why?
• Are there plans you could make together to make using the internet safer for your child and their friends?
• It can really help for parents to learn about this in advance.

Great job! You have learnt about how to keep your child safe in your community, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of keeping your child safe! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be proud of yourself!
Do you have time in the next few days to create a community safety map with your child?
Amazing! This is a great way to build trust with your child and keep them safe.
That's okay! Plan to set aside an hour in the next few days to work with your child on this map. It's a great way to build trust with your child and keep them safe.
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Today's skill is about creating routines for your child.
Your children will feel more secure and safe when they know what is expected of them and how each day will go. Make a plan with them with time for play, meals, chores, school, and sleep.
Would you like to receive some tips to help you establish routines wiith your child?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Give one instruction at at time.
 
Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!

2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one.

Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"

3. Create regular eating and sleeping times.

Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

Here are some tips for how to help your child prepare for bedtime:

• Try to have regular bedtimes each day as much as possible.
• Try to make it quiet and the lights in the room dim. 
• Spend some time with your child. You can sing a lullaby or tell a calm story.
• Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

4. Involve your child in creating daily routines.

Involve your child in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!

Here are some suggestions for routines that you could establish with your children: Bedtime Schoolwork and Online Classes Chores Mealtime Play/free time T.V. or gadget time Storytime One-on-One Time You can add more, too! Here is a comic on creating a daily routine with your child.
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: “Now let’s look at the multiplication tables…”

(1)

Parent: “Thank you for helping me make lunch, Junior” 

Child: “My favourite!”

(2)

Child: “My favourite!”

(3)

Parent “And they all lived happily ever after…Goodnight, my love.”

(4)

Parent: "Thank you for being so supportive with the kids today.” 

(5)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Amazing! You have learnt about how to create routines with your child, and you have earned yourself another badge.  You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of keeping your child safe! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be proud of yourself!
Are you ready to begin setting routines?
That's great! Start creating at least one regular daily routine, like having a meal together or sharing a story before bedtime. It will help your child feel secure and loved!

That's okay! Beginning something new takes time. Start by speaking to a family member about how you should approach using routines. Sometimes speaking to others can increase your confidence and give you ideas on which routines could be useful for your child. For instance, you could have dinner together or read a bedtime story!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Today's skill is about learning what to do when our children misbehave. All children misbehave sometimes. It is normal when they are tired, scared, hungry, or learning independence.
Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"
Learning how to redirect behaviour will help you achieve your goal of improving your child's behaviour!

Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
Would you like to get a comic on how to use redirect?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Child: “Give it to me!”

(1)

Teen: “I had it first!” 

(2)

Parent: “Cameron and Billy, come and help me prepare dinner. We are making your favourite dish!”

(3)

Parent: “Thank you for helping me get these veggies clean for our dinner tonight!”

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Well done! You have learnt how to redirect your child's behaviour and you have earned yourself another badge!
You are one step closer to achieving your goal of improving your child's behaviour! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, your are a superparent!
Are you ready to begin redirecting your child's negative behaviour?
Amazing! We love your enthusiasm! Over the next few days, try redirecting your child from a negative behaviour to a positive one before it gets worse. You can do it!

That's okay! Sometimes it takes time to begin using a new parenting technique. You can always review this skill in the Main Menu! Start by making a list of small negative behaviours you would like to address and think of positive alternatives. Sometimes feeling prepared helps to give you the confidence to start something new!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video that helps you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.
Here's a audio message that helps you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.
Today's skill is about learning how to solve problems with your child.

As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe. This can create conflict at home, however learning about to work together to solve callenges, can help improve your child's behaviour and your relationship.

Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:
1. Identify the problem
2. Think of possible solutions
3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
4. Choose one solution 
5. Try it out!
6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution

You are a star and have gotten yourself another badge! You have learnt how to solve problems with your child!  You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of improving your child's behaviour! You have completed X out of X skills. You should be proud of yourself!

Next time your teen is confronted with a challenge, remain calm and tackle the challenge together. Helping your teen learn how to solve problems will be something they will take with them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!
Here's a video to help you teach your child problem-solving skills!
Here's an audio message to help you teach your child problem-solving skills!
Today's skill is about setting rules.
Household rules can help keep our children safe from potential dangers both inside the house and in the community. They also help children to know what kind of behaviour is expected from them.

Here are some simple tips on how you can make household rules with your children and teens: 
• Involve your child in establishing household rules.
• Make your household rules clear and specific.
• Make sure your child understands the reasons why you are establishing a household rule.
• Make your household rules fair and realistic (just like instructions).
• Praise and simple incentives can help support your child in following a household rule.
• Add only 1 household rule at a time.
missing
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: “Jack, you have been spending a lot of time on your tablet. Why do you think I am concerned about that?”

(1)

Parent: “Yes, that is one reason. It is important that you make the time for your schoolwork. I also like seeing you being more active. Maybe we can make a household rule about gadget use. What do you think would be a fair limit each day?” 

Child: “Um…two hours a day?”

(2)

Child: “How about one hour for fun and one hour for learning?

(3)

Parent: “That sounds reasonable. I would also like you to do your schoolwork before using any gadgets. So from now on, the household rule is that you do your schoolwork before using gadgets and that you can have 1 hour for free time and 1 hour for educational activities. Okay?” 

Child: “Okay.”

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Amazing! You have learnt about how to use rules with your child, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of keeping your child safe! You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Now that you have learnt all about setting rules, are you ready to start using what you learnt?
That's great to hear! Create one household rule with your child. Remember, when you involve your child in making household rules, they are more likely to follow them. It's a recipe for success!

That's okay! Setting rules takes time and practice. Think about what rules you would like to set and, when you feel more confident, talk about these rules with your child. Remember, you can always review this skill in the Main Menu! You got this!

Today's skill is about learning what we can do when our children are already misbehaving or have already misbehaved…
We would like to begin by knowing more about how you discipline your child.

How many days in the past week did you physically discipline your children by hitting, spanking, or slapping with your hand or an object like a stick or a belt? (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)

If you don't want to answer, please type 99.
It is wonderful that you are responding in a calm way when your child does something upsetting. They can learn so much from you!

It sounds like you are having a difficult time with your child. This can be really hard so be patient with yourself. Try to take a pause (even one deep breath!) next time and respond differently. You can do it!

Sorry, I don't understand what you mean. Please reply with a number between 0 and 7.
If you don't want to answer, please type 99.

Giving calm consequences help teach our children responsibility for what they do. They also allow discipline that is controlled. This is more effective than hitting or shouting.
Would you like to receive 5 tips for using consequences?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1. Give a choice before consequence.

Give your child a choice to follow your instruction before giving them the consequence.

2. Try to stay calm but firm when giving the consequence.

If you start yelling, it will just make things worse. Take a deep breath before you speak in a clear, calm, and firm voice.

3. Be realistic and follow through.

Make sure you can follow through with the consequence. For example, taking away a teenager’s phone for a week is hard to enforce. Taking it away for one hour is more realistic.

4. Reconnect afterwards. 

Once the consequence is over, give your child a chance to do something good, and praise them for it.

5. Consequences for breaking rules.

Consequences can also be used when your children forget a household rule, like going to bed at a certain hour or doing schoolwork before T.V.
For example, you can tell your child that if they do not do their schoolwork before dinner, they cannot watch their favourite T.V. show that evening.
Would you like to receive a comic  that shows a parent giving their child a choice to follow the instruction or receive a consequence?
That's okay. You can access the comic in the main menu whenever you want.

Parent: “In 5 minutes it will be time to give me back the phone and start your school work.” 

Teen (distractedly): “Uh-huh…”

(1)

Parent: “5 minutes is up. Please give me the phone.” 

Teen: “No, I am not done. I just need to get to the next level.”

(2)

Parent: “You have a choice, either you give me the phone now, or you cannot use it after dinner.” 

Teen (not happy but agreeing): “Fine.”

(3)

Parent: “Thank you for giving me the phone back, Carter. Now please do your school work. After that we can take a walk or play a game together.”

(4)
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Amazing work! You had learnt how to use appropriate consequences! You are one badge closer to achieving your goal of improving your child's behaviour! You have completed X out of X skills. You are brilliant!

Over the next few days, when your child is behaving badly, respond in a calm way with a fair consequence. It will help them learn that their actions have an impact on themselves and others. It also teaches them about responsibility and respect!
Here's a video that explains how you can use consequences to discipline your child.
Here's an audio message that explains how you can use consequences to discipline your child.

flows.name: PLH module - Learning through play baby

actions.text: Today's skill is about Learning through Play.
Babies love play! We now know that babies learn through play and play is important for healthy development and lifelong learning. Through play, babies will learn to be the best person they can be.
You play an important role in how your baby learns. Learning through play happens best when it is joyful, meaningful, active, flexible, and social.
Would you like to receive some on how you and identify and support your baby’s play and learning?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Bring joy to learning! 

The fun and joy that babies experience during play gives them the motivation to learn. Through play, they are learning how to experience, feel and deal with different emotions. As a caregiver, allow your baby to express their emotions and mirror their joy when you are with them.

Finding meaning in learning.

Babies find learning easier when it is connected to something they already know. For babies, this can be done by connecting new information to people or routines they are familiar with. By giving your baby more attention, they can make sense of what's happening by recalling previous interactions with them.

Focus on learning.

Playful learning is best when it captures your baby's attention and interest, keeping them effortlessly engaged in what they are doing. Babies love play that engages all their senses. Think of activities that include interesting sound, taste, touch, smell, and sights.

Praise your child’s effort.

Everybody makes mistakes and this is an important part of learning. Be supportive and kind so your baby feels safe to make mistakes and approach challenges from different ways. Encourage and praise their efforts even when they are getting things wrong.

Encourage group learning.

Babies are born with the need to socialise and learn best when interacting and playing with their caregivers and other babies. By allowing them to engage with others, they learn how to engage with other people, understanding their views, emotions and needs.

Well done! You have gone through the learning through play skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of helping my child with learning and development. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Are you ready to use what you learnt today and help your baby learn through play?

The next time your baby wants attention, get involved as much as you can and positively respond to any behaviour or emotion that your baby shows. When your baby notices that you are interested in what they are doing, they will keep trying to interact with you to learn more about you and the world.

That's okay! Learning through Play can sound more difficult than it is. Start small and put aside 10 minutes a day to play with your baby. Learning will happen naturally, as babies want to learn and are curious about the world around them!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video on Learning Through Play.
Here's a audio message on Learning Through Play.

flows.name: PLH module - Learning through play child

actions.text: Today's skill is about Learning through Play.

For a child's successful development, it is important that they learn to play, and play to learn. Play is more than just having fun, it promotes all skills your children will need to have a healthy life.
You play an important role in how your child learns. Learning through play happens best when it is joyful, meaningful, active, flexible, and social.
Would you like to receive some on how you and identify and support your child's play and learning?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Bring joy to learning! 

When they're having fun, it is an easy way to notice that your child is learning through play. Caregivers can facilitate playful learning by making sure that the activities are social (e.g., buildings friendships), physically active, challenging but achievable, and filled with laughter and happiness.

Finding meaning in learning.

Children find learning easier when it is connected to something they already know. Try and help your child connect what they are learning to things that they have already learned at school and home.  

You can link their homework to memorable events or experiences such as stories they know, songs they have heard before, family events they were part of, math homework, or tv shows and movies they watch.

Focus on learning.

Playful learning is best when it captures the child's attention and interest, keeping them effortlessly engaged in what they are doing.  

Activities that build on a child’s interest will get them to engage with what they’re learning for longer. If a child is very interested in animals, they will focus on learning for longer if the lesson revolves around animals.

Praise your child’s effort.

Everybody makes mistakes and this is an important part of learning. Be supportive and kind so your child feels safe to make mistakes and approach challenges from different ways. Encourage and praise their efforts even when they ae getting things wrong.

Encourage group learning.

Children do not only learn from adults, but they also learn from their peers and friends. Encourage social interactions. This will help your child learn how to treat and interact with others, be flexible and understand other people’s points of view, which are social and emotional skills your child will need for their future.

Well done! You have gone through the learning through play skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of helping my child with learning and development. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Are you ready to use what you learnt today and help your child learn through play?

That's great! The next time your child is doing a activity, get involved and ask your child questions about what they are doing. When your child notices that you are interested in what they are doing and asking them important questions, it motivates them to keep learning! You got this!

That's okay! Learning through Play can sound more difficult than it is. Start small and put aside 10 minutes a day to play with your child. Learning will happen naturally, as children want to learn and are curious about the world around them. You got this!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video on Learning Through Play.
Here's a audio message on Learning Through Play.

flows.name: PLH module - Learning through play teen

actions.text: Today's skill is about Learning through Play.
Every child is born with the ability to play and learn. Play does not end with childhood, but it is an important part of your teen’s development.
You play an important role in how your teen learns. Learning through play happens best when it is joyful, meaningful, active, flexible, and social.
Would you like to receive some on how you and identify and support your teen’s play and learning?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Bring joy to learning! 

Learning is best when you are having fun! If you notice your teen is smiling, laughing, or celebrating while trying to do something, this is a great sign, and you should encourage it more.

Finding meaning in learning.

Knowledge is power. Learning is more than memorizing and your teens can learn how to apply what they learn during an activity to real life experiences.  

You can help your teen by asking questions about what they learnt. For example, when your child reads a book, ask how the story relates to what is happening in their life.

Create a learning space.

Learning requires focus. Try to create a space where your teen has time to learn without any distractions. This will help them focus and understand things quicker.  

Ask your teen what their goal is before starting a learning activity. If your teen achieved their goal, praise them for their accomplishment. If not, it is okay! Ask them what they could do next time to achieve their goal.

Praise your teen’s effort.

Learning is all about having the freedom to make mistakes! Help your teen explore different ways to solve problems and celebrate their effort. In fact, putting in effort is more important than mastering a specific skill.  

Practice and trying again develops your teen’s brain and allows them to be flexible and creative thinkers.

Encourage group learning.

Learning how to work and play with other people is a very important skill. Encourage social interactions by allowing your teen to learn with others. This helps develop their language and their ability to form stable relationships with others.

Well done! You have gone through the learning through play skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of helping my child with learning and development. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Are you ready to use what you learnt today and help your teen learn through play?

That's great! The next time your teen is learning a new activity, get involved by asking them questions about what they are doing. When your teen notices that you are interested in what they are doing and asking them important questions, it motivates them to keep learning! You got this!

That's okay! Learning through Play can sound more difficult than it is, and it's best to start small. Put aside 10 minutes a day to spend time playing with your teen. When you are having fun, learning will happen naturally, as teens want to learn and are curious about the world around them. You got this!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video on Learning Through Play.
Here's a audio message on Learning Through Play.
Today's skill is about Book Sharing.
Book-sharing can be a great learning tool for your child. You can use simple pictures in books, magazines, or newspapers to do lots of things that you and your child can enjoy.
Would you like to receive some tips on book sharing?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Follow your child’s interest.

Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest.

Use a lively voice.

Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

Pointing and naming.

Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

Be positive and supportive.

Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red tomato and says “Apple”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's a tomato!”

Making actions and links.

Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

Talking about feelings.

Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

Here are some examples! 
“Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
“The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
“That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

Babies and Books! 

Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

Well done! You have gone through the shared reading skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of helping my child with learning and development. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Do you have time today to read with your baby?
That's great! Sharing books with your baby will help them learn to speak, think, and focus better. It builds their brain!

That's okay! Sometimes it's hard to find the time. In the next few days, when you have a few minutes to spare, pick up a book and read with your baby. It's not only great for your baby, it can also be fun for you!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video to take you through the shared book reading activity!
Here's an audio message that takes you through the shared book reading activity!
Today's skill is about helping our children learn.
It is normal to feel overwhelmed about how to best support your child's learning, especially when we also have stress about work and money.
Would you like to receive tips to help your child learn?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Create a routine around learning and schoolwork.

Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

Make learning fun and playful.

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!

Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.

Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

Find out how to stay in touch with your children’s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.

Well done! You have gone through the helping your child learn skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of helping my child with learning and development. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!
Do you have time to create a learning plan with your child?
That's great! Helping your child learn is so important. Your best efforts will make a difference!
That's okay! Getting involved in your child's learning can seem scary at first! To build your confidence, review this skill and give it a go! You got this!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
Here's a video to help you support your child's learning.
Here's an audio message to help you support your child's learning.
Today's skill is about having a peaceful and loving home.

When we are able to have peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved. Kindness and taking care of yourself help. Learning how to have loving relationships at home will help improve family relationships.
Would you like to receive some tips on how to support family harmony at home?
That is okay! We can continue working on this skill tomorrow. Have a great day!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

Be a model of behaviour for your kids.

How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children. The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel."

Use positive language. It works!

Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference.

Be a great listener

Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”

Share the load.

Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members.

Take care of yourself.

Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break

Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.

You can always type "Help" if you need an activity to help you with stress.

Do nice things together as a family.

Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!

Amazing job! You have gone through the making a happy and peaceful  home skill, and you have earned yourself another badge. You are one skill closer to achieving your goal of improving relationships in my family. You have completed X out of X skills. Well done, you a great parent!

Over the next few days, try taking a deep breath or walking away for a bit when you start getting angry at someone. Every time you find a way to resolve conflicts in a peaceful way, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you do it!
Here's a video to help you support positive family relationships at home.

Today's skill is about having a loving relationship with our partner.

Having a loving relationship with our partner can have a big impact on how we feel. It also helps make our children feel loved and safe.  Learning how to have loving relationships at home will help improve family relationships.

1. Treat each other as equals

Family and friends might tell you how a partner or a parent should act. But both men and women benefit when they talk to each other and make decisions together! For example, next time you’re making a decision, try involving your partner and ask what they think.

2. Become a confident parent and a supportive partner

When mothers and fathers are both engaged with the parenting of their children, everyone benefits, including the children! Show your partner that you appreciate it when they spend quality time with your children.

3. Share family responsibilities

Sharing family responsibilities with your partner can make life less stressful! Can you think of ways you can share the workload? Doing tasks together can also make them more fun!

4. Resolve conflict peacefully

All adults have disagreements sometimes. But solving issues through fighting is not effective. Instead, if you start feeling angry, walk away for a bit or take a deep breath before responding in a calmer way.

5. Listen and talk to each other

Listening and talking to those around us is key to a more peaceful home. Talking to your partner about issues before they become problems can help avoid arguments from building up.
